listing.name: Magic Realism: Art in Weimar Germany 1919-33
listing.subtitle: Painting Between the Wars

tip.text:
The Weimar Republic was definitely a pretty lit place to be, WW1 was over and no one thought there would be another. It was a time of opulence, free spiritedness and risk taking. Think cabaret, jazz, martinis and sex - yes, it was like a very well rounded night out.

The paintings from this era, by the likes of Otto Dix, George Grosz, Albert Birkle and Jeanne Mammen, depict sex workers in negligee and crazy nights on the town, alongside the dark debauchery of a post-war society. Many of the works were banned by the Nazis, for being too erotic and promoting life outside of mainstream society, but thankfully, they are now safe and sound, ready for your appraisal on the walls of the Tate.

Estimated Dwell Time: 2hrs

Jenny Holzer makes art with words. She strings them together, puts them on buildings and other public places, plasters them on walls. But her words aren't just banal units of language - they're inflammatory, incendiary, often sad, rousing, political. Jenny is the damn queen of words, and you should go see what she has to say at the Tate.

This exhibition includes works from the artists most significant projects - Truisms, Living, Survival and Laments - plus some rarely-seen pieces. Her aim is to make the viewer slow down and consider the impact of words in an ever-accelerating world, and interrogate the imperfect nature of communication in general. This is certainly not one to miss - but don't worry, you have a whole year to catch it.

Soak up some international culture this summer without having to dig out your passport at the re-vamped World Gallery at the Horniman Museum - a gigantic cabinet of global curiosities. It contains over 3,000 absurd objects, giving glimpses into cultures from all over the world. You’ll certainly have an educational trip and learn how diseases are cured, children are raised and people celebrate birthdays all around the world, throughout the ages; there’s everything from art objects to fertility totems. There is a tinge of voyeuristic colonialism in the air… although maybe that’s just the aromatic herbs used by Bhutanese ritual healers in the Himalayas.

Estimated Dwell Time: 2hrs

This glittering, spectacular exhibition of couture dresses, sketches, films and perfumes is a golden opportunity to get inspiration for evening gowns you will never wear to fancy balls you will never be invited to. But it’s nice to dream right? From a magnificent dress Princess Margaret wore at her 21st to the iconic New Look silhouette which sent shockwaves through post-war rationing Europe, this show looks back at the storied history of the mega-watt fashion house with meters upon meters of silk and more pleats than you’ll know what to do with.

Sure, it kinda glosses over some of the John Galliano years to avoid that thorny anti-semitic rant of his, but Dior is not a brand that deals in matters of stark reality - it’s all about enormous tulle skirts, cinched waists and pastel coloured fantasy, so indulge.

Estimated dwell time: 1 hour 30 mins
